oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Yearbook of the Company 420, Tennessee SP-12 in District C of the Civilian Conservation Corps in Bristol, Tennessee. There is a history of Company 420, as well as photographs of of the camp facilities and activities, including the mess hall, woodworking shop, canteen, recreation hall and basketball team. There are pictures of the company officers and enrollees. Work projects featured include working on roads, stripping limestone, stone masonry, surveying and equipment maintenance.

With the purpose of relieving unemployment, the Civilian Conservation Corps was created in 1933, and was expanded by Congress in 1937. During this expansion, the Civilian Conservation Corps added vocation training and remedial education programs. The Corps employed young men to perform structural improvements to bridges and roads; erosion and flood control; and various conservation work projects. The Corps was instrumental in the infrastructure of the Tennessee State Parks System and National Parks in Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Conservation of natural resources
Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Big Ridge Park Public Lodge under construction.

Big Ridge Park is a heavily forested, 3,687-acre park which lies on the southern shore of Tennessee Valley Authority's Norris Reservoir, approximately 25 miles north of Knoxville. It was one of five demonstration parks developed by the Tennessee Valley Authority in cooperation with the National Park Service and the Civilian Conservation Corps (C. C. C.) as an example of public recreation development along Tennessee Valley Authority lakeshores. The structures on the park reflect the craftsmanship and stonework of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Empty all-purpose 223rd Company Civilian Conservation Corps room at Powell's Station, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Spencer & Wycoff
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Each Civilian Conservation Corps camp was located in the general area of particular conservation work to be performed, and organized around a compliment of up to 200 civilian enrollees in a designated numbered "company" unit. Each camp was structured to have barracks for 50 enrollees, officers/technical staff quarters, medical dispensary, mess hall, recreation hall, educational building, lavatory and showers, technical/administrative offices, tool room/blacksmith shop and motor pool garages.

Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939

oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bledsoe State Forest is located on the Cumberland Plateau in east-central Tennessee, in Bledsoe, Cumberland, Van Buren, and White Counties. In 1934, a Civilian Conservation Corps (C. C. C.) camp [1466] was established and remained; on the forest until 1940. Several buildings, roads, and trails were constructed during this time. The C. C. C. planted hundreds of thousands of trees which make up many of the pine stands that you see on the forest today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Conservation of natural resources
Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Inside of a Civilian Conservation Corps barracks at Powell's Station, Tennessee. Foot lockers are at the foot of each bunk. Laundry bags, containing dirty clothes, hang from the walls.; Many of the bunks are arranged with alternating feet and heads.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Spencer & Wycoff
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The foot lockers at the foot of each bunk were to contain the workers' personal items nd clothing. The alternating head and feet pattern of the bunks was to keep the workers from talking to each other at night. It was also thought to slow the spreading of germs.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Conservation of natural resources; Soil conservation
Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two unidentified officers of Civilian Conservation Corps Camp No. 496 standing in front of headquarters.

Captain Hoke S. O'Kelly was commanding officer of Civilian Conservation Corps Camp 496 which was created to combat soil erosion and was located in Lexington, TN. The Civilian Conservation Corps facilitated the spread of kudzu by planting millions of seedlings as part of an extensive soil erosion project.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hobart Parrish comments on Civilian Conservation Corps recruitment
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hobart Parrish talking about joining the Civilian Conservation Corps. He speaks about recruitment site at Bethel College and not being old enough to join the Civilian Conservation Corps, so his birthday was changed from 1917 to 1916 to make him a year older and allow him to join the Civilian Conservation Corps a year earlier than he should have. He took a train to Montgomery County and was encamped at Clarksville, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Interview conducted by Wayne Moore, recording made by Greg Yates.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hobart Parrish comments on the Great Depression and the New Deal
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hobart Parrish describing how aware he was of the conditions in the Great Depression and the New Deal. He saw pictures from New York or Pittsburgh of people in soup lines. In his area they were unable to sell produce but mostly raised their own food. They only had to buy certain items (like salt and black pepper) from peddling wagons. The Depression made it difficult to make money, but didn't impact rural areas in the same manner as it did in the towns.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Interview conducted by Wayne Moore, recording made by Greg Yates.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hobart Parrish on his motivations to join the Civilian Conservation Corps
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hobart Parrish describing what attracted him to join the Civilian Conservation Corps. He could get an education, earn money, and learn a trade. It was difficult to go to college, and he felt he would get the same preparation in the Civilian Conservation Corps taking their training in various trades. He also felt that if he did want to go to college he would be able to save money he made and could afford it. He also comments on the amounts of pay he received in Civilian Conservation Corps, how much he was given and how much the Civilian Conservation Corps sent home to his family.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Interview conducted by Wayne Moore, recording made by Greg Yates.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hobart Parrish describing his Civilian Conservation Corps camp in Clarksville
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Parrish's camp was constructed outside the city limits at the time, but would be inside the city limits today. They could walk to town and go to movies. He also attended night school at Clarksville High School, which was permitted in the Civilian Conservation Corps. Some Civilian Conservation Corps men went to Austin Peay as well. He also took courses given at the camp, such as engineering, soil conservation, mechanics, blacksmithing, or forestry. He mostly took engineering classes. Civilian Conservation Corps leaders also taught crews about how to prevent erosion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Interview conducted by Wayne Moore, recording made by Greg Yates.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hobart Parrish comments on the attitude of Clarksville locals toward the Civilian Conservation Corps
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Parrish states that he believes when the Civilian Conservation Corps first ecamped outside Clarksville the locals were a taken aback by their presence, but after a while they became accepted, and locals even provided them lunch. They eventually became a soil conservation service camp. Their original camp number, SCS8, reflects this. The camp's forestry number had been P63 when they were a forestry camp. Camps were numbered according to the kind of work the camp specialized in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Interview conducted by Wayne Moore, recording made by Greg Yates.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hobart Parrish comments on racial integration in Civilian Conservation Corps camps
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Parrish states that no African-Americans were in his camp, but the people in the camp were from all over the country. The camp at Montgomery Bell State Park was African-American and moved to Centerville area. The camp at Crossville moved to Montgomery Bell, and it was a white camp. Also comments on how camps were assigned and which parks were worked on by the numerous Civilian Conservation Corps camps in Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hobart Parrish on the typical length of time in the Civilian Conservation Corps
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Upon enlisting in the Civilian Conservation Corps you're supposed to stay 6 months, and most stayed 6 months. They were supposed to discharge a camp member after 2 years. Because of the work he was doing and his position as Civilian Conservation Corps camp assistant, which was a civil service job, he was able to stay in for five years. During his civil service he no longer stayed at the camp but worked there and was still in the Civilian Conservation Corps. Also comments that some individuals, like Frank Sinatra, stayed briefly in the Civilian Conservation Corps and left due to lack of interest.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Interview conducted by Wayne Moore, recording made by Greg Yates.

oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Parrish states that the Tennessee Valley Authority had 40 camps, such as the ones at Pickwick and Norris Dam. Pickwick was built by Civilian Conservation Corps, but the camp was operated by the Tennessee Valley Authority. They did work the Tennessee Valley Authority needed done rather than the soil conservation work they did in regular Civilian Conservation Corps camps. Tennessee Valley Authority camps had a Tennessee Valley Authority number and an army number that stayed with them when they changed locations as long as they continued to do the same work.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bulletin boards; Signs (Notices); Forests; Trees
Forest reserves; Public service employment; Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Foreground image of rustic bulletin board communicating conservation and safety message with a backdrop of lush trees in Pickett State Forest.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee-- Dept. of Conservation
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: RG 82, Department of Conservation Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Civilian Conservation Corps did the initial development of the Pickett State Forest site following the donation of the 12,000 acres to the state by Stearns Coal and Lumber Company in 1933. Between 1934 and 1942, hiking trails, cabins, a lodge, a ranger station, and a 12-acre lake were put in place. Much native sandstone rock was used by the Civilian Conservation Corps in building construction. Civilian Conservation Corps employees quarried the stone from the area. The Park appears on the National Register of Historic Places.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hobart Parrish comments on the Civilian Conservation Corps as a recovery organization
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The money made by the Civilian Conservation Corps could be spent by the family and it would help the towns that it went to. A butchershop owner once told Parrish if it hadn't been for Civilian Conservation Corps money he would've had to close. It helped the Civilian Conservation Corps families, the shop owners, and the towns. Boys in the camps learned a trade and the ones that played music or had comedic talent performed in the camps. While on the Mississippi River doing flood control, one worker drowned; that is the only fatality from his camp he is aware of.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Interview conducted by Wayne Moore, recording made by Greg Yates.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hobart Parrish comments on rules and discipline in the Civilian Conservation Corps
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civilian Conservation Corps (U.S.); New Deal, 1933-1939
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Parrish recalls that no Civilian Conservation Corps workers he knew of ever got into trouble while he was in the camp. He states they didn't always behave, but they never got caught. There was an officer in Clarksville who wanted to catch men from the Civilian Conservation Corps camp misbehaving. There was a bootlegger that supplied them with whiskey and the officer tried to catch Civilian Conservation Corps boys going there but never had any luck. Also comments on how camps enforced their own rules and policed themselves. Comments on different denominations of churches.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: With the purpose of relieving unemployment, the Civilian Conservation Corps was created in 1933, and was expanded by Congress in 1937. During this expansion, the Civilian Conservation Corps added vocation training and remedial education programs. The Corps employed young men to perform structural improvements to bridges and roads; erosion and flood control; and various conservation work projects. The Corps was instrumental in the infrastructure of the Tennessee State Parks System and National Parks in Tennessee. The T. O. Fuller State Park was established as a segregated park. It is famous for such Native American archaeological sites as Fuller Mounds.
